title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: James splits 4 packs of stickers that have 30 stickers each.  Each sticker cost $.10.  If his friend pays for half how much did James pay?

He got 4*30=<<4*30=120>>120 stickers
So each sticker cost .10 so James paid 120*.10=$<<120*.10=12.00>>12.00
His friend paid half so he paid 12/2=$<<12/2=6.00>>6.00. Answer: \boxed{6}.


Question: James splits 4 packs of stickers that have 30 stickers each.  Each sticker cost $.10.  If his friend pays for half how much did James pay?

He got 4*30=<<4*30=120>>120 stickers
So he got half of these for 120/2=<<120/2=60>>60 stickers
That means he paid for 120-60=<<120-60=60>>60 stickers
That means he paid 60*$0.10=$<<60*0.10=6>>6. Answer: \boxed{6}.


Question: James splits 4 packs of stickers that have 30 stickers each.  Each sticker cost $.10.  If his friend pays for half how much did James pay?

He split 4 packs of stickers that have 30 stickers so he has 4*30 = <<4*30=120>>120 stickers
He pays for half of them so he pays 120/2 = <<120/2=60>>60 stickers
Each sticker cost $.10 and he bought 60 stickers so he paid .10*60 = $<<.10*60=6.00>>6.00. Answer: \boxed{6}.


Question: James goes out to eat.  He orders a steak and egg meal for $16.  He is with his friend, who orders chicken fried steak for $14.  His friend pays for half the bill and James pays the tip along with his half of the bill. They tip 20%.  How much did James pay?

The cost of half of the food bill is 16+14=<<16+14=30>>30 dollars
The tip came out to be 30*.2=$<<30*.2=6>>6
So James paid 30/2+6=$<<30/2+6=21>>21. Answer: \boxed{21}.


Question: James goes out to eat.  He orders a steak and egg meal for $16.  He is with his friend, who orders chicken fried steak for $14.  His friend pays for half the bill and James pays the tip along with his half of the bill. They tip 20%.  How much did James pay?

The meal cost 16+14=$<<16+14=30>>30
The tip came out to 30*.2=$<<30*.2=6>>6
So James paid 30/2=$<<30/2=15>>15 for his half
So James paid 15+6=$<<15+6=21>>21. Answer: \boxed{21}.


Question: James splits 4 packs of stickers that have 30 stickers each.  Each sticker cost $.10.  If his friend pays for half how much did James pay?
text:
He got 4*30=<<4*30=120>>120 stickers
So each sticker cost .10 so James paid 120*.10=$<<120*.10=12.00>>12.00
His friend paid half so he paid 12/2=$<<12/2=6>>6. Answer: \boxed{6}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: To keep himself busy in class, Michael makes rubber-band balls. He makes two sizes, large and small. A small ball uses 50 rubber bands. A large ball requires 300 rubber bands. Michael brought a 5,000 pack to class and already made 22 small balls. How many large balls can he make with the remaining rubber bands?

Michael has used 50 x 22 = <<50*22=1100>>1100 rubber bands.
The remaining rubber bands is 5000 - 1100 = <<5000-1100=3900>>3900.
Thus, Michael can make 3900/300 = <<3900/300=13>>13 large rubber band balls. Answer: \boxed{13}.


Question: To keep himself busy in class, Michael makes rubber-band balls. He makes two sizes, large and small. A small ball uses 50 rubber bands. A large ball requires 300 rubber bands. Michael brought a 5,000 pack to class and already made 22 small balls. How many large balls can he make with the remaining rubber bands?

After building small balls, Michael has 5000 – 22 * 50 = <<5000-22*50=3900>>3900 rubber bands left.
Therefore, he can make 3900 / 300 = <<3900/300=13>>13 large balls. Answer: \boxed{13}.


Question: To keep himself busy in class, Michael makes rubber-band balls. He makes two sizes, large and small. A small ball uses 50 rubber bands. A large ball requires 300 rubber bands. Michael brought a 5,000 pack to class and already made 22 small balls. How many large balls can he make with the remaining rubber bands?

Michael has used 22 x 50 = <<22*50=1100>>1100 rubber bands to make small balls.
So, he still has 5000 - 1100 = <<5000-1100=3900>>3900 rubber bands left.
Therefore, he can make 3900/300 = <<3900/300=13>>13 large balls. Answer: \boxed{13}.


Question: To keep himself busy in class, Michael makes rubber-band balls. He makes two sizes, large and small. A small ball uses 50 rubber bands. A large ball requires 300 rubber bands. Michael brought a 5,000 pack to class and already made 22 small balls. How many large balls can he make with the remaining rubber bands?

Michael has used 22 * 50 = <<22*50=1100>>1,100 small rubber bands.
He has 5,000 - 1,100 = <<5000-1100=3900>>3,900 rubber bands left after making small balls.
Michael can make 3900 / 300 = <<3900/300=13>>13 large rubber band balls. Answer: \boxed{13}.


Question: To keep himself busy in class, Michael makes rubber-band balls. He makes two sizes, large and small. A small ball uses 50 rubber bands. A large ball requires 300 rubber bands. Michael brought a 5,000 pack to class and already made 22 small balls. How many large balls can he make with the remaining rubber bands?

To make 22 small rubber band balls Michael has used 22 * 50 = <<22*50=1100>>1,100 rubber bands.
He still has 5000 - 1100 = <<5000-1100=3900>>3,900 rubber bands left.
He can make another 3900 / 300 = <<3900/300=13>>13 large rubber band balls. Answer: \boxed{13}.


Question: To keep himself busy in class, Michael makes rubber-band balls. He makes two sizes, large and small. A small ball uses 50 rubber bands. A large ball requires 300 rubber bands. Michael brought a 5,000 pack to class and already made 22 small balls. How many large balls can he make with the remaining rubber bands?
text:
Michael has used a total of 22*50 = <<22*50=1100>>1100 rubber bands to make small balls. 
Subtracting this number from the total number of rubber bands brought to class, we have 5000-1100 = <<5000-1100=3900>>3900 rubber bands remaining. 
Since each large ball requires 300 rubber bands, we can divide the remaining number of rubber bands by 300 to find the number of large balls that can be made. 
Therefore, Michael can make 3900/300 = <<3900/300=13>>13 large rubber band balls. 
Answer: \boxed{13}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: There are 11 males & 12 females in the orchestra and twice that number in the band. There are 12 males & 17 females in the choir. If each musician only participates in one group, how many musicians total are there in the orchestra, the band, and the choir?

There are 11 males + 12 females = <<11+12=23>>23 musicians in the orchestra.
There are 23 musicians * 2 = <<23*2=46>>46 musicians in the band.
There are 12 males + 17 females = <<12+17=29>>29 musicians in the choir.
There are 23 musicians + 46 musicians + 29 musicians = <<23+46+29=98>>98 total musicians. Answer: \boxed{98}.


Question: There are 11 males & 12 females in the orchestra and twice that number in the band. There are 12 males & 17 females in the choir. If each musician only participates in one group, how many musicians total are there in the orchestra, the band, and the choir?

There are 11 males + 12 females = <<11+12=23>>23 musicians in the orchestra.
There are 23 musicians in the orchestra * 2 = <<23*2=46>>46 musicians in the band.
There are 12 males + 17 females = <<12+17=29>>29 musicians in the choir.
There are 23 + 46 + 29 = <<23+46+29=98>>98 musicians total. Answer: \boxed{98}.


Question: There are 11 males & 12 females in the orchestra and twice that number in the band. There are 12 males & 17 females in the choir. If each musician only participates in one group, how many musicians total are there in the orchestra, the band, and the choir?

There are 11 + 12 = <<11+12=23>>23 musicians in the orchestra.
There are twice as many musicians in the band as in the orchestra and choir, so there are 23 x 2 = <<23*2=46>>46 musicians in the band.
There are 12 + 17 = <<12+17=29>>29 musicians in the choir.
Therefore, there are 23 + 46 + 29 = <<23+46+29=98>>98 musicians total among the three groups. Answer: \boxed{98}.


Question: There are 11 males & 12 females in the orchestra and twice that number in the band. There are 12 males & 17 females in the choir. If each musician only participates in one group, how many musicians total are there in the orchestra, the band, and the choir?

There are 11 males + 12 females = <<11+12=23>>23 people in the orchestra.
There are 23 people in the orchestra * 2 = <<23*2=46>>46 people in the band.
There are 12 males + 17 females = <<12+17=29>>29 people in the choir.
There are 23 people + 46 people + 29 people = <<23+46+29=98>>98 musicians total. Answer: \boxed{98}.


Question: A choir splits into 3 groups for their performances. The first group has 25 members, and the second group has 30 members. The third group has the remaining members of the choir. If the choir overall has 70 members, how many members are in the third group?

The combined number of members in the first and second group is 25 + 30 = <<25+30=55>>55 members
The third group has 70 - 55 = <<70-55=15>>15 members. Answer: \boxed{15}.


Question: There are 11 males & 12 females in the orchestra and twice that number in the band. There are 12 males & 17 females in the choir. If each musician only participates in one group, how many musicians total are there in the orchestra, the band, and the choir?
text:
There are 11 males + 12 females = <<11+12=23>>23 musicians in the orchestra.
There are 23 musicians in the orchestra * 2 = <<23*2=46>>46 musicians in the band.
There are 12 males + 17 females = <<12+17=29>>29 musicians in the choir.
Therefore, there are 23 + 46 + 29 = <<23+46+29=98>>98 musicians total among the three groups. Answer: \boxed{98}.

title:

Question: At the feline sanctuary, there were 12 lions, 14 tigers, and several cougars.  If there were half as many cougars as lions and tigers combined, then what was the total number of big cats at the feline sanctuary?

The total number of lions and tigers at the sanctuary is 12 + 14 = <<12+14=26>>26.
Therefore, the number of cougars at the sanctuary is 26 / 2 = <<26/2=13>>13.
So, the total number of big cats at the sanctuary is 12 + 14 + 13 = <<12+14+13=39>>39. Answer: \boxed{39}.

text:
The number of lions and tigers combined at the feline sanctuary is 12 + 14 = <<12+14=26>>26.
Since there were half as many cougars as lions and tigers combined, there were 26 ÷ 2 = <<26/2=13>>13 cougars.
Therefore, the total number of big cats at the feline sanctuary is 26 + 13 = <<26+13=39>>39. Answer: \boxed{39}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Deborah has four letters to mail. Standard postage is $1.08 per letter, with an additional charge for international mail. Deborah is mailing two letters internationally, and she is paying $4.60 to mail four letters. How many cents is the additional charge per letter for international shipping?

Deborah is paying $4.60 - $1.08 * 4 = $4.60 - $4.32 = $0.28 for international shipping.
The additional charge per letter for international shipping is $0.28 / 2 = $<<0.28/2=0.14>>0.14. Answer: \boxed{14}.


Question: Deborah has four letters to mail. Standard postage is $1.08 per letter, with an additional charge for international mail. Deborah is mailing two letters internationally, and she is paying $4.60 to mail four letters. How many cents is the additional charge per letter for international shipping?

The cost for standard postage is $1.08 * 4 = $<<1.08*4=4.32>>4.32.
Deborah must pay 4.60 - 4.32 = $<<4.60-4.32=0.28>>0.28 in additional fees.
Each letter has an additional charge of $0.28 / 2 = $<<0.28/2=0.14>>0.14. Answer: \boxed{14}.


Question: Deborah has four letters to mail. Standard postage is $1.08 per letter, with an additional charge for international mail. Deborah is mailing two letters internationally, and she is paying $4.60 to mail four letters. How many cents is the additional charge per letter for international shipping?

The total cost for four letters mail is 4 * 108 = <<4*108=432>>432 cents.
The cost of sending two letters internationally is therefore 432 - 460 = <<432-460=-28>>-28 cents.
Thus, the additional charge per letter for international shipping is 28 / 2 = <<28/2=14>>14 cents. Answer: \boxed{14}.


Question: Deborah has four letters to mail. Standard postage is $1.08 per letter, with an additional charge for international mail. Deborah is mailing two letters internationally, and she is paying $4.60 to mail four letters. How many cents is the additional charge per letter for international shipping?

Deborah is paying $4.60 total shipping costs. Each letter costs $1.08 to ship. Therefore, $4.60 - ($1.08 \times 4) = $4.60 - $4.32 = $<<4.60-4.32=0.28>>0.28 of her shipping costs is the additional charge for international shipping. Since there are 2 international letters, the price per letter for international shipping is $0.28 / 2 = $0.28 / \frac{28}{100} = \frac{28}{2} / \frac{28}{100} = 14 / \frac{1}{100} = \boxed{14}.$


Question: Dorothy, Julia, and Robert go to the store to buy school supplies. Dorothy buys half as many pens as Julia. Julia buys three times as many pens as Robert. Robert buys 4 pens. If one pen costs $1.50, how much money did the three friends spend in total on pens?

Julia bought 3 * 4 pens = <<3*4=12>>12 pens.
Dorothy bought 12 pens / 2 = <<12/2=6>>6 pens.
The total cost of the pens is 4 pens * $1.50 per pen + 12 pens * $1.50 per pen + 6 pens * $1.50 per pen = $6 + $18 + $9.
The three friends spent a total of $<<6+18+9=33>>33 on pens. Answer: \boxed{33}.


Question: Deborah has four letters to mail. Standard postage is $1.08 per letter, with an additional charge for international mail. Deborah is mailing two letters internationally, and she is paying $4.60 to mail four letters. How many cents is the additional charge per letter for international shipping?
text:
Deborah is mailing a total of 4 letters. Since the standard postage is $1.08 per letter, the total cost for standard postage would be 4 * $1.08 = $4.32. 

The total cost for mailing four letters, including international mail, is $4.60. To find the additional charge per letter for international shipping, we can subtract the cost of standard postage from the total cost: $4.60 - $4.32 = $0.28.

Since Deborah is mailing 2 letters internationally, the additional charge per letter for international shipping is $0.28 / 2 = $0.14.

Therefore, the additional charge per letter for international shipping is 14 cents. Answer: \boxed{14}.

title:

Question: Bert made 12 sandwiches for his trip. On the first day, he ate half of the sandwiches he made. The next day he ate 2 sandwiches less. How many sandwiches does Bert have left after these two days?

On the first day, Bert ate half of the sandwiches he made, which is 12 / 2 = <<12/2=6>>6 sandwiches.
Then he ate 2 sandwiches less, which is 6 - 2 = <<6-2=4>>4 sandwiches.
So, Bert has 12 - 6 - 4 = <<12-6-4=2>>2 sandwiches left. Answer: \boxed{2}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: There are 50 passengers on a bus.  At the first stop, 16 more passengers get on the bus. On the other stops, 22 passengers get off the bus and 5 passengers more get on the bus. How many passengers are there on the bus in total at the last station?

At the first stop, the total number of passengers becomes 50+16 = <<50+16=66>>66
At the other stops, the total number increases to 66+5 = <<66+5=71>>71
After some people get off at the other stations, the number of people on the bus reduces to 71-22 = <<71-22=49>>49. Answer: \boxed{49}.


Question: There are 50 passengers on a bus.  At the first stop, 16 more passengers get on the bus. On the other stops, 22 passengers get off the bus and 5 passengers more get on the bus. How many passengers are there on the bus in total at the last station?

At the first stop, the total number of passengers on the bus is 50 + 16 = <<50+16=66>>66 passengers.
The number of passengers on the bus after the first stop is 66 - 22 = <<66-22=44>>44 passengers.
In the last stop, the number of passengers on the bus becomes 44 + 5 = <<44+5=49>>49 passengers. Answer: \boxed{49}.


Question: There are 50 passengers on a bus.  At the first stop, 16 more passengers get on the bus. On the other stops, 22 passengers get off the bus and 5 passengers more get on the bus. How many passengers are there on the bus in total at the last station?

At the first stop, there are 50 + 16 = <<50+16=66>>66 passengers on the bus.
At the subsequent stops, 66 - 22 = <<66-22=44>>44 passengers are left on the bus.
After that, 44 + 5 = <<44+5=49>>49 passengers are on the bus at the last stop. Answer: \boxed{49}.


Question: The bus started its route. At its first stop, 7 people got on. At the second stop, 3 people got off, and 5 people got on. At the third stop, 2 people got off, and 4 people got on. How many passengers are now on the bus?

The bus started with 0 passengers. At the first stop, 7 people got on, so there are now 0 + 7 = <<0+7=7>>7 passengers on the bus.
At the second stop, 3 people got off, so there are now 7 - 3 = <<7-3=4>>4 passengers on the bus.
At the second stop, 5 people got on, so there are now 4 + 5 = <<4+5=9>>9 passengers on the bus.
At the third stop, 2 people got off, so there are now 9 - 2 = <<9-2=7>>7 passengers on the bus.
At the third stop, 4 people got on, so there are now 7 + 4 = <<7+4=11>>11 passengers on the bus. Answer: \boxed{11}.


Question: There are 50 passengers on a bus.  At the first stop, 16 more passengers get on the bus. On the other stops, 22 passengers get off the bus and 5 passengers more get on the bus. How many passengers are there on the bus in total at the last station?

At the first stop, the number of passengers increases by 16, so there are 50 + 16 = <<50+16=66>>66 passengers on the bus.
On the other stops, 22 passengers get off the bus, so only 66 - 22 = <<66-22=44>>44 passengers are left.
At the other stops, 5 more passengers get on the bus, so in total there are 44 + 5 = <<44+5=49>>49 passengers on the bus at the last stop. Answer: \boxed{49}.


Question: There are 50 passengers on a bus.  At the first stop, 16 more passengers get on the bus. On the other stops, 22 passengers get off the bus and 5 passengers more get on the bus. How many passengers are there on the bus in total at the last station?
text:
At the first stop, the number of passengers increases by 16, so there are 50 + 16 = 66 passengers on the bus.
On the other stops, 22 passengers get off the bus, so only 66 - 22 = 44 passengers are left.
At the other stops, 5 more passengers get on the bus, so in total there are 44 + 5 = 49 passengers on the bus at the last stop. Answer: \boxed{49}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Mr Castiel prepared 600 boar sausages on the weekend. He ate 2/5 of them on Monday, half of the remaining on Tuesday and saved the rest for Friday. If he ate 3/4 of the remaining boar sausages on Friday, how many sausages are left?

Mr Castiel ate 2/5 x 600 = <<2/5*600=240>>240 sausages on Monday.
So, he still has 600 - 240 = <<600-240=360>>360 sausages left on Tuesday.
Then, he ate 360/2 = <<360/2=180>>180 sausages on Tuesday.
Thus, he saved 360 - 180 = <<360-180=180>>180 sausages for Friday.
Therefore, he ate 3/4 x 180 = <<3/4*180=135>>135 sausages on Friday.
Therefore, he has 180 - 135 = <<180-135=45>>45 sausages left. Answer: \boxed{45}.


Question: Mr Castiel prepared 600 boar sausages on the weekend. He ate 2/5 of them on Monday, half of the remaining on Tuesday and saved the rest for Friday. If he ate 3/4 of the remaining boar sausages on Friday, how many sausages are left?

On Monday, Mr Castiel ate 2/5*600 = <<2/5*600=240>>240 sausages
The total number of sausages remaining is 600-240 = <<600-240=360>>360
On Tuesday, Mr Castiel ate 1/2*360 = <<1/2*360=180>>180 sausages
He saved 360-180 = <<360-180=180>>180 for Friday.

On Friday, Mr Castiel ate 3/4*180 = <<3/4*180=135>>135 sausages.
He had 180-135 = <<180-135=45>>45 sausages left. Answer: \boxed{45}.


Question: Mr Castiel prepared 600 boar sausages on the weekend. He ate 2/5 of them on Monday, half of the remaining on Tuesday and saved the rest for Friday. If he ate 3/4 of the remaining boar sausages on Friday, how many sausages are left?

Mr Castiel ate 2/5 * 600 sausages = <<2/5*600=240>>240 sausages on Monday.
He had 600 sausages – 240 sausages = <<600-240=360>>360 sausages left after Monday.
He ate 360 sausages / 2 = <<360/2=180>>180 sausages on Tuesday.
He had 360 sausages – 180 sausages = <<360-180=180>>180 sausages left after Tuesday.
He ate 3/4 * 180 sausages = <<3/4*180=135>>135 sausages on Friday.
He had 180 sausages – 135 sausages = <<180-135=45>>45 sausages left. Answer: \boxed{45}.


Question: Mr Castiel prepared 600 boar sausages on the weekend. He ate 2/5 of them on Monday, half of the remaining on Tuesday and saved the rest for Friday. If he ate 3/4 of the remaining boar sausages on Friday, how many sausages are left?

Mr Castiel ate 2/5*600 = <<2/5*600=240>>240 boar sausages on Monday.
The number of boar sausages remaining is 600-240= <<600-240=360>>360 sausages.
On Tuesday, he ate 1/2*360 = <<1/2*360=180>>180 of the remaining boar sausages.
The number of boar sausages remaining for Friday is 360-180 = <<360-180=180>>180
On Friday, Mr Castiel ate 3/4 * 180 = <<3/4*180=135>>135 of the remaining boar sausages.
The number of boar sausages left is 180-135 = <<180-135=45>>45. Answer: \boxed{45}.


Question: Sam the butcher made sausage by grinding up 10 pounds of spicy meat mix, loading it into a tube casing, and creating a string of 40 sausage links. Then, she hung up the string of sausage links in her cooler.  Later that evening, Brandy, Sam’s Golden Retriever, broke into the cooler and ate 12 links of sausage.  After Brandy’s feast, how many ounces of sausage meat were contained in the remaining links?

Sam made a total of 40 sausage links, and Brandy ate 12 of them, so there were 40 links - 12 links = <<40-12=28>>28 links remaining.
Each link was made from a 10-pound meat mix, so the remaining links utilize only 10 pounds/ 40 links = <<10/40=.25>>.25 pounds/link.
Because each pound contains 16 ounces, each remaining link now has .25 pounds/link * 16 ounces/pound = 4 ounces/link.
With 28 links remaining, the total quantity of remaining sausage meat weighs 4 ounces/link * 28 links = <<4*28=112>>112 ounces. Answer: \boxed{112}.


Question: Mr Castiel prepared 600 boar sausages on the weekend. He ate 2/5 of them on Monday, half of the remaining on Tuesday and saved the rest for Friday. If he ate 3/4 of the remaining boar sausages on Friday, how many sausages are left?
text:
On Monday, Mr Castiel ate 2/5 * 600 sausages = 240 sausages.
So he had 600 sausages - 240 sausages = 360 sausages left on Tuesday.
On Tuesday, he ate 1/2 * 360 sausages = 180 sausages.
Thus, he saved 360 - 180 sausages = 180 sausages for Friday.
On Friday, he ate 3/4 * 180 sausages = 135 sausages.
Therefore, he has 180 - 135 sausages left. Answer: \boxed{45}.
